container-title: United States private initiatives by businessmen and civic leaders saw the founding of museums in major cities throughout the 1870s and 1880s: the Museum of Fine Arts
note: the Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York (both founded
title: South Kensington Museum in 1852), natural history museums engaged in the Darwinian enterprise (such as the Oxford University Museum, opened 1860), and museums established by local councils in county towns or boroughs after the Museum Act of 1845 (such as the Salford, Bolton, and Rochdale museums in the industrial north). These last were an amalgam, combining fine and decorative arts, local archaeology, Egyptian antiquities, and natural history.
